revision.text:
'''James Greenwood''' (c.1683 – 1737) was an English [[Linguist|grammarian]].
==Life== Greenwood was for some time usher to Benjamin Morland (1657-?) at [[Hackney Academy]], but soon after 1711 opened a boarding-school at [[Woodford, Essex]]. At midsummer 1721, when Morland became [[High Master (academic)|high-master]], he was appointed surmaster of [[St. Paul's School, London]], a post which he held until his death on 12 September 1737.<ref>[[Gentleman's Magazine]]; 1737, p. 574</ref> He left a widow, Susannah.
==Works== He is mostly known as the author of ''An Essay towards a practical English Grammar. Describing the Genius and Nature of the English Tongue'', &c., 12mo, London, 1711 ; 2nd edit. 1722; 3rd edit. 1729; 5th edit. 1753 (reprinted by the [[University of Michigan Library]], 2009). It received the praises of Andrew Ross, Professor of Humanity at the [[University of Glasgow]], Dr. [[George Hickes (divine)|George Hickes]], [[John Chamberlayne]], and [[Isaac Watts]], who in his ''Art of Reading and Writing English'' considered that Greenwood had shown in his book "the deep Knowledge, without the haughty Airs of a Critick". At Watts's suggestion Greenwood afterwards published an abridgment under the title of ''The Royal English Grammar'', which he dedicated to the [[Caroline of Ansbach|Princess of Wales]]; the fourth edition of this appeared in 1750, an eighth in 1770.
The appearance of two other English grammars by John Brightland (d. 1717) and [[Michael Mattaire]] at about the same time called forth an anonymous attack on all three books, entitled ''Bellum Grammatical; or the Grammatical Battel Royal. In Reflections on the three English Grammars publish'd in about a year last past'', 8vo, London, 1712.
Greenwood also wrote ''The London Vocabulary, English and Latin: put into a new Method proper to acquaint the Learner with Things, as well as Pure Latin Words. Adorn'd with Twenty Six Pictures'', &c., 3rd edition, 12mo, London 1713 (many editions, both English and American). It is, however, nothing more than an abridgment of [[Comenius|Jan Amos Komensky]]'s ''Orbis Pictura''. Greenwood's last work was ''The Virgin Muse. Being a Collection of Poems from our most celebrated English Poets … To which are added some Copies of Verses never before printed; with notes'' &c., 12mo, London, 1717; 2nd edition, 1722. It does not appear that Greenwood himself was a contributor.
==References== {{reflist}} {{DNB|wstitle=Greenwood, James}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}}

[[File:Prof James M Lindsay.jpg|right|thumb|James M. Lindsay in 2009.]] '''James M. Lindsay''' (born November 29, 1959, [[Winchester, Massachusetts]]), is the Senior Vice President, Director of Studies, and Maurice R. Greenberg Chair at the [[Council on Foreign Relations]] (CFR) and a leading authority on [[U.S. foreign policy]]. He is also the award-winning coauthor of [http://www.cfr.org/publication/9028/america_unbound.html ''America Unbound: The Bush Revolution in Foreign Policy''] and former Director for Global Issues and Multilateral Affairs at the [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]]. In 2008, he was the principal author of a [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] funded $7.6 million [[Minerva research initiative|Minerva Research Initiative]] grant entitled "Climate Change, State Stability, and Political Risk in Africa."<ref>http://www.defense.gov/releases/release.aspx?releaseid=12407</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://minerva.dtic.mil/funded.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-12-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091212104216/http://minerva.dtic.mil/funded.html |archivedate=2009-12-12 |df= }}</ref> He is the author of a CFR blog on American foreign policy, [http://blogs.cfr.org/lindsay/ The Water's Edge].
==Academic Work== Lindsay holds an A.B. in [[economics]] and [[political science]] (highest distinction, highest honors) from the [[University of Michigan]] and an [[Master of Arts|M.A.]], [[Master of Philosophy|M. Phil.]], and [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] from [[Yale University]].
He has authored, co-authored, or edited more than fifteen books and fifty journal articles and book chapters on various aspects of American foreign policy and [[international relations]]. His latest book, ''[https://www.publicaffairsbooks.com/titles/ivo-h-daalder/the-empty-throne/9781541773875/ The Empty Throne: America's Abdication of Global Leadership],'' co-authored with [[Ivo Daalder|Ivo H. Daalder]] and released in October 2018. His previous book with Ivo H. Daalder, ''America Unbound: The Bush Revolution in Foreign Policy'', was awarded the 2003 [[Lionel Gelber Prize|Lionel Gelber Award]], named a finalist for the Arthur S. Ross Book Award, and selected as a top book of 2003 by ''[[The Economist]]''.
With [[Henry J. Aaron]] and Pietro S. Nivola, he co-edited ''Agenda for the Nation'', which ''Choice'' Magazine named “Outstanding Academic Book of 2004.” In 2001, with [[Michael E. O'Hanlon]], he wrote ''Defending America: The Case for Limited National Missile Defense''.
He is the author of ''Congress and the Politics of U.S. Foreign Policy'', published in 1994; and ''Congress and Nuclear Weapons'', published in 1991. He has also contributed articles to the op-ed pages of many major newspapers, including the [[The New York Times|New York Times]], the [[The Washington Post|Washington Post]], and the [[Los Angeles Times]].
==Research and Government Positions== From 2006 to 2009, Lindsay was the inaugural director of [[The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law]] at [[The University of Texas at Austin]] as well as the first Tom Slick Chair for International Affairs at the [[Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs]]. From 2003 to 2006, he was Vice President, Director of Studies, and Maurice R. Greenberg Chair at the Council on Foreign Relations. From 1999 to 2003, he served as Deputy Director and Senior Fellow in the Foreign Policy Studies Program at the [[Brookings Institution]]. From 1987 to 1999, he was a professor of [[political science]] at the [[University of Iowa]], where he was the recipient of the Collegiate Teaching Award and of the James N. Murray Faculty Teaching Award. In 1996-1997, he was Director for Global Issues and Multilateral Affairs on the staff of the [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]].
He has also served as a consultant to the [[National Commission on Terrorism|United States Commission on National Security/21st Century (Hart-Rudman Commission)]] and as a staff expert for the [[United States Institute of Peace|United States Institute of Peace’s]] Congress-mandated Task Force on the United Nations. He has been a fellow at the Center for International Affairs and the Center for Science and International Affairs, both at [[Harvard University]]. He was a recipient of the [[Pew Research Center|Pew]] Faculty Fellowship in International Affairs in 1990 and an International Affairs Fellowship from the [[Council on Foreign Relations]] in 1995.
==Professional Boards, Committees, and Organizations==
* [[Council on Foreign Relations]], 2000–Present * Editorial Board, ''International Studies Quarterly'', 1999-2002 * Executive Committee, Midwest Consortium for International Security, 1992-1999 * Editorial Board, ''PS: Political Science & Politics'', 1993-1996 * Editorial Board, ''International Studies Perspectives'', 2004–Present

Daalder (2018) *[http://www.brookings.edu/press/books/agendaforthenation.htm ''Agenda for the Nation''], with Henry J. Aaron and Pietro S. Ripley) * [http://www.atomicdog.com/BookDetails.asp?Session=7725A1B0-8400-42AB-8BC9-BC885A1F56E7&BookEditionID=146&Authors=true ''Dynamics of Democracy''], 4ed. {{For|other persons with this name|John Conway (disambiguation){{!}}John Conway}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = [[Civil decorations of Pakistan|SQA]] | name = John Berchmans Conway | birth_date = 1929 | birth_place = [[County Clare]], [[Ireland]] | residence = [[Murree]], [[Pakistan]] | occupation = [[Religious sister]], teacher | honours = [[Civil decorations of Pakistan|Sitara-e-Quaid-i-Azam]] }} '''John Berchmans Conway, [[Religious of Jesus and Mary|R.J.M.]]''' (born '''Bernadette Conway''' in 1929{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}), usually known as '''Sister Berchmans''', is a Roman Catholic [[Nun|religious sister]] and [[Veteran Pakistani Catholic teachers|teacher]] who has been working in Pakistan for 60 years. In 2012 she was decorated by the [[Government of Pakistan]] for her services in education and promoting interfaith harmony.<ref name=trib>{{cite web|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/336573/jesus-and-mary-convent-principal-to-be-honoured-with-sitara-quaid-e-azam/|title=Jesus and Mary Convent principal to be honoured with Sitara-Quaid-e-Azam|work=The Express Tribune|date= February 15, 2012}}</ref>
==Early life== Conway was born in [[County Clare]], Ireland. In 1951 she joined the Congregation of the [[Religious of Jesus and Mary]], founded by [[Claudine Thevenet]] in France in 1818, dedicated to caring for and educating the young and homeless. Very early, the congregation took on the task of education in other countries. The first Convent of Jesus and Mary in Pakistan was opened by four sisters in [[Lahore]] in 1876.<ref name=CH>{{cite journal|url=http://www.exacteditions.com/exact/browse/397/440/30335/3/2|work=The Catholic Herald|date=20 January 2012|first=Ed|last=West|title=Nuns in Pakistan inspire Peer|accessdate=3 August 2013}}</ref> She was sent to Pakistan in 1953 at the age of 24.
== Work in Pakistan== Conway has spent some 60 years teaching. Her passion has been teaching English, although she has also taught mathematics. She has taught girls in Jesus and Mary Convents in [[Convent of Jesus and Mary (Lahore)|Lahore]], [[Convent of Jesus and Mary (Murree)|Murree]] and [[Convent of Jesus and Mary (Karachi)|Karachi]].<ref name=CH />
Conway completed her [[Diamond Jubilee]], or 60th year, of [[religious profession]] in the Religious of Jesus and Mary in December 2011.<ref name=dawn>[http://www.dawn.com/2012/01/16/educationist-a-life-to-celebrate.html Dawn, 16 January 2012] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120032321/http://www.dawn.com/2012/01/16/educationist-a-life-to-celebrate.html |date=January 20, 2012 }}</ref>
Among Conway's notable students were [[Benazir Bhutto]], the late Prime Minister of Pakistan, who was assassinated in 2007,<ref name=CH /> and [[Asma Jahangir]], a noted human rights activist.<ref name=UCA>{{cite web|url=http://www.ucanews.com/2012/03/27/government-rewards-church-people/|work= UCANews |title=Government rewards Church people|date=March 27, 2012|first=Ayyaz|last=Gulzar}}</ref>
In 2012 Conway was still serving as the Principal of the Convent of Jesus & Mary in Karachi.<ref name=trib />
==Award== On 15 February 2012, the President of Pakistan approved conferment of the ''Sitara'' ([[Urdu]]: Star) class of the [[Nishan-e-Quaid-i-Azam]] award on Conway for her services in education and promoting interfaith harmony in Pakistan.<ref name=trib />
On 25 March 2012, more than 600 people gathered at [[St. Anthony’s Parish (Karachi)|St. Anthony’s Church]] for a special [[mass (liturgy)|Mass]] to celebrate the conferral of the country’s highest civilian award on Conway and [[the Rev.]] [[Robert McCulloch (priest)|Robert McCulloch]], [[Missionary Society of St. Columban|S.S.C.]]<ref name=UCA />

{{redirects|Finance Park|the Stavros Institute program in Florida|Stavros Institute|business parks in general|business park}} {{advert|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox non-profit | Non-profit_name = JA (Junior Achievement) Worldwide | Non-profit_logo = Junior Achievement Logo.svg | logo_size = 220px | Non-profit_type = [[501c3]] | founded_date = 1919 | founders = [[Theodore Vail]], [[Horace A. Moses]], [[Winthrop M. Crane]] | location = [[Boston, MA]], [[Massachusetts]] | origins = | key_people = | area_served = Worldwide | product = | mission = To inspire and prepare young people to succeed in a global economy | focus = | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | homepage = https://www.jaworldwide.org/ | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
'''JA (Junior Achievement) Worldwide''' is a global [[Non-profit organization|non-profit]] [[youth organization]] founded in 1919 by [[Horace A. Moses]], [[Theodore Vail]], and [[Winthrop M. Crane]]. JA works with local businesses, schools, and organizations to deliver [[experiential learning]] programs on the topics of [[work readiness]], [[financial literacy]], and [[entrepreneurship]] to students from ages 5 to 25.<ref name="1990 NY Times article">{{cite news|last=Daley|first=Suzanne|title=New World for Junior Achievement|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/28/education/new-world-for-junior-achievement.html?src=pm|accessdate=16 May 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=28 November 1990}}</ref><ref name="1997 NY Times article">{{cite news|last=Singer|first=Penny|title=For Junior Achievers, Volunteers Are Key|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/18/nyregion/for-junior-achievers-volunteers-are-key.html?src=pm|accessdate=16 May 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=18 May 1997}}</ref><ref name="2012 Washington Post article">{{cite news|last=Heath|first=Thomas|title=Value Added: This English major prefers the language of money|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/value-added-this-english-major-prefers-the-language-of-money/2012/05/13/gIQAmYcGNU_story.html|accessdate=16 May 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=13 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Duchon|first=Dennis|author2=Green, Stephen G. |author3=Taber, Thomas D. |title=Vertical dyad linkage: A longitudinal assessment of antecedents, measures, and consequences.|journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|date=1 January 1986|volume=71|issue=1|pages=56–60|doi=10.1037/0021-9010.71.1.56|url=http://psycnet.apa.org/journals/apl/71/1/56/|accessdate=16 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Wagner|first=Jodie|title=Junior Achievement program teaches Jupiter students life skills|url=https://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/local-education/junior-achievement-program-teaches-jupiter-students-life-skills/GryFfBxEKcTdtBcBU633zK/|publisher=The Palm Beach Post|date=16 November 2012}}</ref>
== History == ''Boys' and Girls' Bureau of the Eastern States League'' was founded in [[Springfield, Massachusetts]], in 1919 to help educate young people moving from rural America to the country's booming cities about the means of production and free enterprise. The following year, the organization's name was changed to the Junior Achievement Bureau. The name was modified in 1926 to Junior Achievement, Inc.<ref name=IU>{{cite web|title=Junior Achievement Records, 1916-2002, Ruth Lilly Special Collections & Archives|url=http://www.ulib.iupui.edu/special/collections/philanthropy/mss048|publisher=Indiana University|accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref>
Following World War II, the organization grew from a regional into a national organization.<ref name=francomano>{{cite book|last=Francomano|first=Joe|title=Junior Achievement: A History|year=1988|publisher=Junior Achievement Inc.|location=Colorado Springs, CO|pages=|url=https://www.jaworldwide.org/aboutja/}}</ref> In the 1960s, JA began its growth into an international organization.<ref name=francomano/>
For more than 50 years, the organization was known mostly for the JA Company Program, an after-school program through which students form companies, sell stocks, produce and market a product, and sell it in their communities and globally. The student companies are mentored by volunteer advisers from the business and tech communities. In 1975, Junior Achievement introduced its first in-school program, Project Business, featuring volunteers from the local business community teaching middle school students about business and personal finance.<ref name=francomano/>
Today, JA Worldwide is one of the world's largest organization youth-serving organizations, dedicated to giving young people the knowledge and skills they need for employment and entrepreneurship. JA programs are delivered by corporate and community volunteers and provide relevant, hands-on experiences that give students knowledge and skills in financial literacy, work readiness, and entrepreneurship. JA annually reaches more than 10 million students in more than 100 countries around the world. Programs are delivered by more than 450,000 JA volunteers.<ref name="JA Worldwide18">{{cite web|title=JA Worldwide Locations|url=https://www.jaworldwide.org/locations/ |accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref>
JA Worldwide has regional offices in [http://www.ja.org Junior Achievement USA], [http://www.injazalarab.org JA Middle East and Africa] ([[INJAZ Al-Arab]]), [http://jaeurope.org JA Europe], [http://www.jaasiapacific.org JA Asia Pacific], [http://www.jaamericas.org JA Americas], and [http://www.jainafrica.org/ JA Africa].<ref name="JA Worldwide18"/>
Several other organizations have joined JA Worldwide, such as Young Enterprise in the UK, INJAZ in the Middle East, Prestasi Junior in Indonesia, and [[Vlaamse Jonge Ondernemingen|Vlajo]] in [[Belgium]].
== Notable Alumni ==
Notable JA alumni include former U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services [[Donna Shalala]], U.S. Congressman [[Bob Clement]], Subway restaurant founder [[Fred DeLuca]], American actor [[Arte Johnson]], journalist [[Dan Rather]], [[Dallas Mavericks]] owner [[Mark Cuban]], comedian [[Amy Sedaris]], and British Labor Party Politician [[David Lammy]].<ref name="JA100">{{cite web|title=Junior Achievement 100|url=https://www.jaworldwide.org/100lives |accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="JANash">{{cite web|title=Junior Achievement of Middle Tennessee|url=http://www.janash.com/about-us/founders |accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref><ref name=JAPress012018>{{cite web|title=Junior Achievement Looking to Re-Connect with Former Students|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/junior-achievement-looking-to-re-connect-with-former-students-300576695.html |publisher=Junior Achievement|accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref>
== Programs ==
JA programs for elementary, middle, high school, and college students are designed to "help prepare young people for the real world by showing them how to generate wealth and effectively manage it, how to create jobs which make their communities more robust, and how to apply entrepreneurial thinking to the workplace."<ref name="JA Programs">{{cite web|title=JA Programs|url=https://www.juniorachievement.org/web/ja-usa/ja-programs|accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref>
=== Elementary School === *JA Ourselves (Kindergarten) *JA Our Families (Grade 1) *JA Our Community (Grade 2) *JA More than Money (Grades 3-5) *JA Our City (Grade 3) *JA Our Region (Grade 4) *JA BizTown (Grade 5) *JA Our Nation (Grade 5)
=== Middle School === *JA Economics for Success *JA Global Marketplace *JA It’s My Business! *JA It’s My Future
=== High School === *JA Be Entrepreneurial *JA Career Success *JA Company Program *JA Economics *JA Exploring Economics *JA Finance Park *JA Job Shadow *JA Launch Lesson *JA Personal Finance *JA Titan
== Leadership ==
From its founding in 1919 until 1962, JA was managed by volunteers from the business community. In 1962, the organization hired its first, full-time, paid president.<ref name=IU/>
Leaders of Junior Achievement USA included:
*[[Theodore Newton Vail|Theodore N. Vail]], 1919-1920, [[AT&T]] *[[Horace A. Moses]], 1920-1942, Strathmore Paper *[[Charles R. Hook Sr.|Charles R. Hook]], 1942-1944, [[Armco Steel]] *Robert L. Lund, 1944-1949, [[Warner–Lambert|Lambert Pharmaceutical]] *Earl O. Shreve, 1949-1952, [[General Electric]] *Larry C. Hart, 1952-1956, [[General Electric]] *T.G. Shirreffs, 1956-1958, [[Standard Oil]] *Edwin H. Mosler, Jr., 1958-1962, [[Mosler Safe Company]] *S. Bayard Colgate, 1962-1965, [[Colgate-Palmolive]] *McClain Smith, 1966-1968, [[IBM]] *Bruce Palmer, 1969-1970, [[The Conference Board]] *[[John D. deButts]], 1970-1971, [[AT&T]] *William Elmer, 1971-1973, Texas Gas Corp. *Richard A. Jay, 1973-1975, [[Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company|Goodyear Tire & Rubber]] *Richard L. Terrell, 1975-1977, [[History of General Motors|General Motors]] *[[Frank T. Cary]], 1977-1979, [[IBM]] *[[David T. Kearns]], 1979-1981, [[Xerox]] *Dennis R. Hendrix, 1981-1983, Texas Gas Corp. *[[John A. Young]], 1983-1985, [[Hewlett-Packard|Hewlett-Packard Co.]] *Hicks B. Waldron, 1985-1987, [[Avon Products]] *[[Lodwrick Cook|Lodwrick M. Cook]], 1987-1989, [[ARCO]]
== National Conference ==
Beginning in 1944, Junior Achievement organized an annual national conference, known as the National Junior Achievers Conference, NAJAC, to bring together student representatives of local programs to participate in contests. In 1949, the organization began allowing conference delegates to elect national leadership to play an active role contributing to program development, increasing public awareness and supporting fundraising.<ref name=IU/>
From 1944 to 1961, conferences were held in New Jersey, West Virginia, Ohio and Indiana, before finding a permanent home on the campus of [[Indiana University]] in [[Bloomington, Indiana]], where delegates have gathered in August of each year since 1962.<ref name=IU/>
=== National Conference Presidents ===
Between 1949 and 1989, 33 teenagers, including 31 boys and 2 girls, were elected by their peers to serve as Junior Achievement's national conference president.<ref name=IU/>
*1949 Robert Preston, Chicago, IL *1953 Dick Hagens, Dayton, OH *1954 Roger Alvey, Bridgeport, CT *1955 Donald Smith, South Bend, IN *1956 Patrick Oliver, Detroit, MI *1957 James Turnball, Detroit, MI *1958 William Browder, Bessemer, AL *1959 Michael Redman, Seattle, WA *1960 Robert L. Walker III, Nashville, TN *1961 James Harrington, Chicago, IL *1962 Calvin Scott, Ypsilanti, MI *1963 Michael Hannigan, Jr., South Bend, IN *1965 Mike Arthur, Southeastern, MI *1966 Guy Martin, Birmingham, AL *1967 John Nelson, Houston, TX *1968 Chris Streifender, Warrensville Heights, OH *1969 Rodney Miller, Dallas, TX *1970 Sharion Patterson, Phoenix, AZ *1971 Don Didier, Rockford, IL *1972 Phil Shewmaker, Louisville, KY *1975 Rick Talley, Jr., Philadelphia, PA *1976 Gene Musser, Willow, PA *1977 David Harris, Cambridge, MA *1978 Stuart Baum, Sherman Oaks, CA *1979 Seth Eisenberg, Falls Church, VA *1980 Michael Liss, Cincinnati, OH *1981 John Tipton, Louisville, KY *1982 Michael Bishop, Jacksonville, FL *1983 Richard Titsworth, Sylvania, OH *1984 Dennis Lemenager, Worcester, MA *1986 Jeff Brown, Machensey Park, IL *1987 William Harper, Watson, AL *1988 Laura Donohue, Santa Clara, CA *1989 Dan Chapman, Lexington, KY

{{coord|50|25|53|N|30|31|00|E|scale:2000_region:UA|display=title}} [[File:Киевский планетарий. фасад.JPG|thumb|Kiev Planetarium in January 2012]] [[File:Киевский планетарий. Аппарат "Большой цейс - 4".JPG|thumb|Planetarium projector of the Kiev Planetarium]] '''Kiev Planetarium''' (previously ''Republican Planetarium''; {{lang-uk|Київський планетарій}}) in [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]] is one of the largest [[Planetarium|planetaria]] in the [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]] (former Soviet states). Opened on January 1, 1952 by the initiative of the scientist-astronomer Serhiy Vsekhsviatskiy (1905–1984), the planetarium has a dome of 23.5 meters in diameter, and seats 320 people.
In 1987, Kiev Planetarium moved to new premises on the street. Red Army, 57 /3, where he remains to this day. The new building was set device " Large Zeiss IV», allowing to demonstrate the 6500 stars of the Northern and Southern hemispheres. The planetarium offers lectures on astronomy, geography, natural history. When the children's planetarium astronomical school for students 6–11 years of age and art studio. Kiev Planetarium is a division of the Society "Knowledge" of Ukraine.
== Atmasfera 360 ==
In December 2011 an entertainment center ATMASFERA 360 was founded on the basis of the planetarium. Specifications of the dome: diameter - 23 meters, the height of the dome - 11.5 meters. It is equipped with a modern 4k digital projection system supplied by Ukrainian company [[Front Pictures]]. The system uses 15 projectors which work on a single Screenberry media server. Due to digital autocalibration system the calibration process takes up to 15 minutes and includes all 5 stages: * Geometric alignment * Edge blending * Brightness uniformity * Gamma matching * Black level compensation
Atmasfera 360 is equipped with a software, Event Horizon. Event Horizon is a real-time 3D fulldome environment that visualizes and simulates the known Universe according to accurate, up-to-date scientific data. The software is based on the latest Unreal Engine technology and provides up to 4K resolution graphics which, combined with a beautiful soundtrack, gives a revolutionary viewing experience.
==External links== * {{uk icon}}/{{ru icon}} {{Official website|http://planet.org.ua}}

{{refimprove|date=July 2014}} {{use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{infobox artist | name = Kristaq Rama | image = File:Mother Albania Tirana 2.JPG | alt = | caption = Mother Albania. The partisan monument and graveyard on the outskirts of Tirana, Albania. | birth_name = <!--only use if different from name--> | birth_date = 1932 | birth_place = [[Durrës]], [[Albania]] | death_date = April 1998 (aged 65–66) | death_place = [[Tirana]], [[Albania]] | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | alma_mater = | known_for = [[Sculpture]] | notable_works = | style = | movement = | spouse = | awards = <!-- {{awd|award|year|title|role|name}} (optional) --> | elected = | patrons = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> }} '''Kristaq Rama''' (1932{{spaced ndash}} April 1998) was an [[Albania|Albanian]] [[sculptor]], art educator and a member of the Politburo in [[Communist Albania]] under [[Enver Hoxha]]'s rule.
== Early life and education == He was born in [[Durrës]].
Rama graduated from the [[Jordan Misja Artistic Lyceum|Artistic Lyceum "Jordan Misja"]], in the Department of Fine Arts in 1951, and three years later left Albania to study in [[Leningrad]], [[Soviet Union]].
==Career== After graduation, he returned to Albania, where he worked in [[Tirana]], primarily as superintendent of fine arts at the [[Ministry of Tourism, Cultural Affairs, Youth and Sports (Albania)|Albanian Ministry of Culture]], and at the same time taught as an external lecturer at the [[Higher Institute of Arts of Tirana]].
== Works == As a sculptor, Rama created several busts of warriors, people portraits, female sculptures, as well as other decorations.
== Implication with communist dictatorship crimes == In August 1988, Rama signed{{spaced ndash}} along with [[Ramiz Alia]] and others<ref>{{dead link|date=July 2014}} [http://www.zeriyt.com/dlattach.html;topic=61595.0;attach=65637;image Death sentence document].</ref><ref>[[:File:Havzi Nela death penalty.jpg|Havzi Nela death penalty]] (in Albanian).</ref>{{spaced ndash}} documents for the [[death penalty]] of poet [[Havzi Nela]] by [[hanging]].<ref>[http://lajme.shqiperia.com/lajme/artikull/iden/367106/titulli/Varja-e-Havzi-Neles-PD-zbardh-vendimin-dhe-firmen-e-Kristaq-Rames Varja e Havzi Nelës, zbardhet vendimi dhe firma e Kristaq Ramës] (in Albanian).</ref><ref>[http://www.gazeta55.al/index.php?kat=politike&artikulli=2717 1988-Kristaq Rama firmosi vendimin me vdekje në litar për Havzi Nelën] (in Albanian).</ref><ref>[http://www.lajmishqip.com/?p=22480 Dënimi i krimeve të komunizmit, guri në qafën e politikës në Shqipëri] (in Albanian).</ref><ref>[http://www.klosi.org/news/klosi_news_oponion/154.html Poeti disident Havzi Nela...] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141007045122/http://www.klosi.org/news/klosi_news_oponion/154.html# |date=7 October 2014 }} (in Albanian).</ref><ref>[http://www.botasot.info/shqiperia/39488/S6u4o0k/ Ja si Kristaq Rama vendosi për varjen në litar të poetit Havzi Nela] (in Albanian).</ref> Other documents show that Rama signed for the death penalty for [[Enver Osmani]], a 29-year-old from [[Dibra]].<ref>[http://www.gazeta55.al/index.php?kat=politike&artikulli=11773 Kristaq Rama, firmë për ekzekutimin e të riut nga Dibra] (in Albanian).</ref>
==Personal life== He is the father of [[Edi Rama]], president of the [[Socialist Party of Albania]] and [[Prime Minister of Albania]], also several times former mayor of Tirana city.<ref>[http://www.ps.al/leadership/ Socialist Party of Albania Leadership] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130206132728/http://www.ps.al/leadership |date=6 February 2013 }}.</ref>
Rama died, age 65–66, in Tirana in 1998.
==See also== {{portal|Albania|Biography|Visual arts}} * [[Art of Albania]] * [[List of Albanians]] * [[List of sculptors]] {{clear}}

{{Infobox scientist | name = Luis von Ahn | image =Wikimania 2015 - Day 2 (18).jpg | caption = Von Ahn at [[Wikimania 2015]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1978|8|19}} | birth_place = [[Guatemala City]], [[Guatemala]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States]] | alma_mater = [[Carnegie Mellon University]]
[[Duke University]] | doctoral_advisor = [[Manuel Blum]] | known_for = [[CAPTCHA]], [[reCAPTCHA]], [[Duolingo]], [[crowdsourcing]] pioneer | awards = [[MacArthur Fellowship]] (2006), [[TR35]] (2007){{cite web|title=Innovators Under 35: 2007|url=http://www2.technologyreview.com/tr35/profile.aspx?TRID=631|publisher=MIT Technology Review|accessdate=13 August 2015}} | work_institution = [[Carnegie Mellon University]] }} '''Luis von Ahn''' ({{IPA-es|ˈlwis fon ˈan|lang}}; born 19 August 1978) is a Guatemalan entrepreneur and a Consulting Professor in the [[Carnegie Mellon School of Computer Science|Computer Science Department]] at [[Carnegie Mellon University]] in [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]].{{cite web|title=Luis von Ahn|url=https://www.cs.cmu.edu/directory/lav|publisher=Carnegie Mellon University|accessdate=13 August 2015}} He is known as one of the pioneers of [[crowdsourcing]]. He is the founder of the company [[reCAPTCHA]], which was sold to [[Google]] in 2009,{{cite news|title=Teaching computers to read: Google acquires reCAPTCHA|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.co.uk/2009/09/teaching-computers-to-read-google.html|accessdate=13 August 2015|work=Google Official Blog|date=16 September 2009}} and the co-founder and CEO of [[Duolingo]], a popular language-learning platform. == Biography == Von Ahn was born in and grew up in [[Guatemala City]]. He is of [[German Guatemalan]] descent. He received his [[Bachelor of Science|BS]] in Mathematics (''[[summa cum laude]]'') from [[Duke University]] in 2000,{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.duke.edu/people/profiles/individual/2010_luis_von_ahn/|title=Duke Ugrad Alum Profile: Luis von Ahn|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Duke University|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170201162052/http://www.cs.duke.edu/people/profiles/individual/2010_luis_von_ahn/|archive-date=17 February 2017|dead-url=|accessdate=13 August 2015}} and later got his [[PhD]] in Computer Science at [[Carnegie Mellon University]] in 2005.https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~biglou/LuisvonAhn_CV.pdf In 2006, Von Ahn became a faculty member at the [[Carnegie Mellon School of Computer Science]], [[Carnegie Mellon University]].{{Cite web|url=https://triblive.com/local/allegheny/14071844-74/duolingo-ceo-luis-von-ahn-wins-500k-lemelson-prize-from-mit|title=Duolingo CEO Luis von Ahn wins $500K Lemelson prize from MIT|last=Federoff|first=Stacey|website=TribLIVE.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-14}} ==Work== As a professor, his research includes [[CAPTCHA]]s and [[Human-based computation|human computation]],{{cite journal | author = Robert J. Simmons | year = 2010 | title = Profile Luis von Ahn: ReCaptcha, games with a purpose | journal = XRDS: Crossroads, The ACM Magazine for Students | volume = 17 | issue = 2 | pages = | doi = 10.1145/1869086.1869102 | url = http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1869102 | format = | accessdate = }} which has earned him international recognition and numerous honors. He was awarded a [[MacArthur Fellow]]ship in 2006,{{cite web|title=MacArthur Fellows 2006 |url=http://www.macfound.org/site/c.lkLXJ8MQKrH/b.2070789/apps/nl/content2.asp?content_id={7D985462-610A-445A-B44A-6238715F94BC}¬oc=1 |publisher=MacArthur Foundation |accessdate=13 August 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609130641/http://www.macfound.org/site/c.lkLXJ8MQKrH/b.2070789/apps/nl/content2.asp?content_id=%7B7D985462-610A-445A-B44A-6238715F94BC%7D¬oc=1 |archivedate=9 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news|title=Congratulations, Luis von Ahn|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.co.uk/2006/09/congratulations-luis-von-ahn.html|accessdate=13 August 2015|work=Google Official Blog|date=19 September 2006}} the [[David and Lucile Packard Foundation]] Fellowship in 2009, a [[Sloan Fellowship]] in 2009, and a [[Microsoft]] New Faculty Fellowship in 2007, and the Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers in 2012.{{cite news|author=Office of the Press Secretary|title=President Obama Honors Outstanding Early-Career Scientists|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2012/07/23/president-obama-honors-outstanding-early-career-scientists|accessdate=13 August 2015|publisher=The White House|date=23 July 2012}} He has also been named one of the 50 Best Brains in Science by ''[[Discover (magazine)|Discover]]'', and has made it to many recognition lists that include ''[[Popular Science]]'''s Brilliant 10, Silicon.com's 50 Most Influential People in Technology, ''[[MIT Technology Review]]'''s [[TR35]]: Young Innovators Under 35, and ''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]'''s 100 Most Innovative People in Business. ''[[Siglo Veintiuno]]'', one of the biggest newspapers in Guatemala, chose him as the person of the year in 2009. In 2011, [[Foreign Policy Magazine]] in Spanish named him the most influential intellectual of Latin America and Spain.{{cite news|title=Los 10 nuevos rostros del pensiamento iberoamericano|url=http://www.fp-es.org/los-10-nuevos-rostros-del-pensamiento-iberoamericano|accessdate=14 August 2015|work=FP|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110529100941/http://www.fp-es.org/los-10-nuevos-rostros-del-pensamiento-iberoamericano|archivedate=29 May 2011|language=es}} Von Ahn's early research{{cite web|title=Luis von Ahn|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=luis+von+ahn|publisher=Google Scholar|accessdate=14 August 2015}} was in the field of [[cryptography]]. With Nicholas J. Hopper and [[John Langford (computer scientist)|John Langford]], he was the first to provide rigorous definitions of [[steganography]] and to prove that private-key steganography is possible. In 2000, he did early pioneering work with [[Manuel Blum]] on CAPTCHAs,Von Ahn, Luis; Blum, Manuel; Hopper, Nicholas J.; Langford, John (May 2003). "CAPTCHA: Using Hard AI Problems for Security". Proceedings of the International Conference on the Theory and Applications of Cryptographic Techniques (EUROCRYPT 2003). computer-generated tests that humans are routinely able to pass but that computers have not yet mastered.{{Cite journal | last1 = Von Ahn | first1 = L. | last2 = Blum | first2 = M. | last3 = Langford | first3 = J. | doi = 10.1145/966389.966390 | title = Telling humans and computers apart automatically | journal = Communications of the ACM | volume = 47 | issue = 2 | pages = 56–60 | year = 2004 | pmid = | pmc = }} These devices are used by web sites to prevent automated programs, or bots, from perpetrating large-scale abuse, such as automatically registering for large numbers of accounts or purchasing huge numbers of tickets for resale by scalpers. CAPTCHAs brought von Ahn his first widespread fame among the general public due to their coverage in the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' and ''[[USA Today]]'' and on the [[Discovery Channel]], [[NOVA scienceNOW]], and other mainstream outlets. Von Ahn's Ph.D. thesis, completed in 2005, was the first publication to use the term "[[Human-based computation|human computation]]" that he had coined, referring to methods that combine human brainpower with computers to solve problems that neither could solve alone. Von Ahn's Ph.D. thesis is also the first work on [[Game with a purpose|Games With A Purpose]], or GWAPs, which are games played by humans that produce useful computation as a side effect. The most famous example is the [[ESP Game]],{{Cite book | last1 = Von Ahn | first1 = L. | last2 = Dabbish | first2 = L. | doi = 10.1145/985692.985733 | chapter = Labeling images with a computer game | title = Proceedings of the 2004 conference on Human factors in computing systems - CHI '04 | pages = 319–326 | year = 2004 | isbn = 1581137028 | pmid = | pmc = }} an online game{{Cite journal | last1 = Von Ahn | first1 = L. | title = Games with a Purpose | doi = 10.1109/MC.2006.196 | journal = Computer | volume = 39 | issue = 6 | pages = 92–94 | year = 2006 | pmid = | pmc = }} in which two randomly paired people are simultaneously shown the same picture, with no way to communicate. Each then lists a number of words or phrases that describe the picture within a time limit, and are rewarded with points for a match. This match turns out to be an accurate description of the picture, and can be successfully used in a database for more accurate image search technology. The ESP Game was licensed by Google in the form of the [[Google Image Labeler]], and is used to improve the accuracy of the [[Google Image Search]]. Von Ahn's games brought him further coverage in the mainstream media. His thesis won the Best Doctoral Dissertation Award from Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science. In July 2006, von Ahn gave a tech talk at Google on "Human Computation" (i.e., crowdsourcing) which was watched by over one million viewers.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tx082gDwGcM Google Tech Talk on human computation by Luis von Ahn]. youtube.com (2006-07-26). Retrieved on 2015-06-12. In 2007, von Ahn invented [[reCAPTCHA]], a new form of [[CAPTCHA]] that also helps digitize books. In reCAPTCHA, the images of words displayed to the user come directly from old books that are being digitized; they are words that [[optical character recognition]] could not identify and are sent to people throughout the web to be identified. ReCAPTCHA is currently in use by over 100,000 web sites and is transcribing over 40 million words per day.[http://blog.newsweek.com/blogs/techtonicshifts/archive/2009/11/13/recaptcha-a-k-a-those-infernal-squiggly-words-almost-done-digitizing-the-new-york-times-archive.aspx reCAPTCHA (a.k.a. Those Infernal Squiggly Words) Almost Done Digitizing the New York Times Archive] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091115172537/http://blog.newsweek.com/blogs/techtonicshifts/archive/2009/11/13/recaptcha-a-k-a-those-infernal-squiggly-words-almost-done-digitizing-the-new-york-times-archive.aspx |date=2009-11-15 }}. Blog.newsweek.com (2009-11-13). Retrieved on 2012-05-13. In 2011, he was awarded the A. Nico Habermann development chair in computer science,[http://news.cs.cmu.edu/article.php?a=2304 Habermmann Chair announcement]. News.cs.cmu.edu (2011-03-14). Retrieved on 2012-05-13. which is awarded every three years to a junior faculty member of unusual promise in the School of Computer Science. In 2018, von Ahn was awarded the [[Lemelson-MIT Program|Lemelson-MIT]] prize for his "dedication to improving the world through technology."{{Cite web|url=https://triblive.com/local/allegheny/14071844-74/duolingo-ceo-luis-von-ahn-wins-500k-lemelson-prize-from-mit|title=Duolingo CEO Luis von Ahn wins $500K Lemelson prize from MIT|last=Federoff|first=Stacey|website=TribLIVE.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-14}} {{As of|2014}}, von Ahn is the CEO of [[Duolingo]], a language education platform.[https://www.duolingo.com/press]. Duolingo.com Retrieved on 2018-02-21. ==Teaching== Von Ahn has used a number of unusual techniques in his teaching, which have won him multiple teaching awards at Carnegie Mellon University.[http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~scsfacts/simon.html CMU Faculty Awards]. Cs.cmu.edu. Retrieved on 2012-05-13. In the fall of 2008, he began teaching a new course at Carnegie Mellon entitled "Science of the Web". A combination of [[graph theory]] and social science, the course covers topics from [[Network theory|network]] and [[game theory]] to [[auction theory]].[http://www.contrib.andrew.cmu.edu/~nkatariy/15396/ 15396 Science of the Web] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104222627/http://www.contrib.andrew.cmu.edu/~nkatariy/15396/ |date=2013-11-04 }}. Andrew.cmu.edu. Retrieved on 2013-11-04. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Luis von Ahn}} *[http://vonahn.blogspot.com/ Luis von Blog, Luis von Ahn's weblog] *{{Twitter}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tx082gDwGcM Google Tech Talk on human computation by Luis von Ahn] *[http://crowdsource.google.com/imagelabeler Google Image Labeler] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120219230749/http://www.macfound.org/site/c.lkLXJ8MQKrH/b.2070789/apps/nl/content2.asp?content_id=%7B7D985462-610A-445A-B44A-6238715F94BC%7D¬oc=1%2F John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation] *[https://caltech.academia.edu/Rankmania2011 Example of SEO Project given at CMU] *[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/sciencenow/0401/04.html Profile: Luis von Ahn] [[NOVA scienceNOW]] aired 2009-06-30 *{{TED speaker}} *{{AcademicSearch|2448700}} *{{DBLP|name=Luis von Ahn}} {{Hopper winners}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Von Ahn, Luis}} [[Category:Guatemalan computer scientists]] [[Category:1978 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:MacArthur Fellows]] [[Category:Carnegie Mellon University alumni]] [[Category:Duke University alumni]] [[Category:Carnegie Mellon University faculty]] [[Category:Human-based computation]] [[Category:People from Guatemala City]] [[Category:Computer science educators]] [[Category:Guatemalan people of German descent]]

revision.text:
{{Use South African English|date=February 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox organization |name = Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority (formerly Ngwao Boswa jwa Kapa Bokone - Heritage Northern Cape) |image = |abbreviation = |formation = 2003 |status = |headquarters = 1 Monridge Office Park, Monument Heights, Kimberley, Northern Cape |region_served = [[Northern Cape]] Province, South Africa |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = Council |website = [http://www.nbkb.org.za Ngwao-Boswa Jwa Kapa Bokone] }} {{Coord| 28|44|8|S| 24|45|56|E| display=title}}
The '''Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority''', previously called '''Ngwao Boswa jwa Kapa Bokone''' (seTswana for 'Heritage Northern Cape'), and commonly known as 'Boswa', is a [[provincial heritage resources authority]] established in 2003 by the [[Executive Council (South Africa)|MEC]] for Sport, Arts and Culture in the [[Northern Cape]] Province of South Africa, and reconstituted in terms of the Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority Act, 2013.<ref>Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority Act, Act No 9 of 2013, Province of the Northern Cape Provincial Gazette Extraordinary, No 1784, 5 March 2014.</ref> It is an institution set up under the terms of the National Heritage Resources Act.<ref>National Heritage Resources Act, Act 25 of 1999, Government Notice 506, Republic of South Africa Government Gazette, Vol. 406, No 19974, Cape Town, 28 April 1999</ref> It is mandated to care for that part of South Africa's national estate that is of provincial and local significance in the [[Northern Cape]].
The Heritage Authority is best known as the custodian of the approximately 130 provincial heritage sites in the province,<ref>[[List of heritage sites in Northern Cape]]</ref> but is also responsible for administration of other forms of protection of heritage established under the terms of the National Heritage Resources Act.
== History == The Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority (sometimes referred to as 'Ngwao Boswa') is the successor body to the former [[National Monuments Council (South Africa and Namibia)|National Monuments Council]] in the [[Northern Cape]] Province of South Africa. Under the 1996 [[Constitution of South Africa]] cultural matters are a competency shared between national and provincial government.<ref>Schedule 4, Part A, Constitution of the Republic of South Africa, Act. 108 of 1996</ref> This necessitated the creation of a system whereby many of the responsibilities of the former National Monuments Council were devolved to provincial level via the National Heritage Resources Act.
The Northern Cape Provincial Government elected initially to use provisions of the National Heritage Resources Act which allowed it to establish a provincial heritage resources authority (PHRA): 'Ngwao Boswa' was established by regulation on 28 February 2003.<ref>Official Notice 5 of 2003, Province of the Northern Cape Provincial Gazette No. 744, Kimberley: 28 February 2003</ref> On 11 October 2003 the Council appointed by the MEC for Sport, Arts and Culture met for the first time and has since met regularly.<ref>Minutes of the First Meeting of the Council of Ngao Boswa Kapa Bokoni, 11 October 2003</ref> The Council established a sub-committee known as the 'Permits Committee' which met monthly to consider applications under the terms of the National Heritage Resources Act.<ref>Section 3.5, Ngwao-Boswa ya Kapa Bokone Annual Report 2009-2010, Kimberley, 2010, Page 4</ref> The Council also established an Executive Committee.<ref>Section 3.2, Ngwao-Boswa ya Kapa Bokone Annual Report 2009-2010, Kimberley, 2010, Page 4</ref>
The Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority Act, 2013, reconstitutes the Council and provides for the governance of the authority, determining its objects, functions and operation, and regulating staff and financial matters.<ref>Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority Act, Act No 9 of 2013, Province of the Northern Cape Provincial Gazette Extraordinary, No 1784, 5 March 2014.</ref>
The authority inherited responsibility for approximately 130 former national monuments, now known as [[Provincial heritage site (South Africa)|‘provincial heritage sites’]].<ref>[[List of heritage sites in Northern Cape]]</ref> The National Heritage Resources Act provides for a greater variety of protection than did its predecessor and the organisation has continued to institute protections of various forms under its terms. A large part of this work is dedicated to transforming the heritage landscape of the [[Northern Cape]] Province to ensure that the heritage of all its people enjoys equal recognition and appropriate protection.
=== Logo === [[File:Gemsbok engraving, Wildebeest Kuil, Kimberley, South Africa.JPG|240px|thumb|The rock engraving of an eland at the [[Wildebeest Kuil Rock Art Centre]] on which the logo of 'Ngwao Boswa' is based.]]
The Logo of the organisation is based on a rock engraving of an [[Eland antelope|eland]] from the [[Wildebeest Kuil Rock Art Centre|Wildebeest Kuil rock art site]], the first new provincial heritage site to be declared by the organisation following its establishment.<ref>General Notice 82 of 2008, Province of the Northern Cape Provincial Gazette No. 1234, Kimberley: 19 September 2008</ref>
=== Name === The initial name of the organisation was a rendition of 'Heritage Northern Cape' in the seTswana language, also translated as 'Erfenis Noord-Kaap' in Afrikaans and 'Amafa Asemntla Koloni' in isiXhosa, English, Afrikaans and isiXhosa being the other three official languages of the province.
From its inception there was controversy over the correct translation of the term 'Heritage Northern Cape' into seTswana, the regulation establishing the organisation spelling it 'Taolo Ya Ngoa Boshwa Kapa Bokoni'.<ref>Official Notice 5 of 2003, Province of the Northern Cape Provincial Gazette No. 744, Kimberley: 28 February 2003</ref> It was also frequently referred to, more correctly, as 'Ngwao-Boshwa [or Boswa] ya [or jwa] Kapa Bokone'.<ref>http://glosbe.com/en/tn/of</ref>
New legislation, published in March 2014, gives the name of the organisation as Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority.
== SAHRA and the Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority's Mandate == The Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority is subject to a biennial assessment of competency by the [[South African Heritage Resources Agency]], SAHRA, in terms of which it is determined which aspects of the National Heritage Resources Act it is qualified to implement.<ref>Section 8(6), National Heritage Resources Act, Act 25 of 1999, Government Notice 506, Republic of South Africa Government Gazette, Vol. 406, No 19974, Cape Town, 28 April 1999</ref> It has been assessed as competent to deal with all areas over which a provincial heritage resources authority is permitted to act, aside from Sections 35 and 36 of the Act which cover certain aspects relating to archaeology, palaeontology, graves and burials.
== Categories of heritage resource for which Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority is responsible == The Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority is responsible for sites that fall within the following categories:<ref>Section3(2), National Heritage Resources Act, Act 25 of 1999, Government Notice 506, Republic of South Africa Government Gazette, Vol. 406, No 19974, Cape Town, 28 April 1999</ref>
* Buildings and structures of architectural, historical, technical and aesthetic value * Places to which oral traditions intangible values are attached * Historical settlements and towns * Landscapes and natural features * Geological sites * Battlefields * Sites associated with slavery
== Staff Complement == The Council of the Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority employs the staff of the organisation, although up to 2011 staff were employees of the Northern Cape Department of Sport, Arts and Culture.
== Formally Protected Sites == [[File:Richtersveld World Heritage Site, Sunset at Rooiberg.JPG|240px|thumb|Sunset near Rooiberg, [[Richtersveld]] World Heritage Site.]] Approximately 130 sites in the Northern Cape are formally protected as [[Provincial heritage site (South Africa)|provincial heritage sites]].<ref>[[List of heritage sites in Northern Cape]]</ref> Most of these were declared under legislation that predates the National Heritage Resources Act and were previously known as 'national monuments'. One new provincial heritage site has been declared by the Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority, that being the [[Wildebeest Kuil Rock Art Centre|Wildebeest Kuil rock art site]] which was gazetted on 19 September 2008.<ref>General Notice 82 of 2008, Province of the Northern Cape Provincial Gazette No. 1234, Kimberley: 19 September 2008</ref> The organisation is also responsible for the [[Richtersveld|Richtersveld World Heritage Site]] which was gazetted as a heritage area on 18 June 2007.<ref>General Notice 64 of 2007, Province of the Northern Cape Provincial Gazette No. 1123, Kimberley: 18 June 2007</ref> In cooperation with municipalities, several other heritage areas have been established in terms of Section 31 of the National Heritage Resources Act and municipal spatial development frameworks. These are in the following towns:
* [[Calvinia]] and [[Nieuwoudtville]] in the [[Hantam Local Municipality]]<ref>Spatial Development Framework, Hantam Municipality, Calvinia, 2011</ref> * [[Carnarvon, South Africa|Carnarvon]] in the [[Kareeberg Local Municipality]]<ref>Spatial Development Framework, Kareeberg Municipality, Carnarvon, 2011</ref> * [[Fraserburg]] in the [[Karoo Hoogland Local Municipality]]<ref>Spatial Development Framework, Karoo Hoogland Municipality, Sutherland, 2011</ref> * [[Port Nolloth]] in the [[Richtersveld Local Municipality]]<ref>Spatial Development Framework, Richtersveld Municipality, Port Nolloth, 2011</ref> * [[Kimberley, South Africa|Kimberley]] in the [[Sol Plaatje Local Municipality]],<ref>Spatial Development Framework, Sol Plaatje Municipality, Kimberley, 2010</ref> * [[Colesburg]] in the [[Umsobomvu Local Municipality]]<ref>Spatial Development Framework, Umsobomvu Municipality, Colesberg, 2011</ref>
== Funding == The Northern Cape Heritage Resources Authority receives an annual transfer payment from the [[Northern Cape]] Department of Sport, Arts and Culture.
== Literature == * http://www.dac.gov.za/acts/a25-99.pdf * National Heritage Resources Act, Act 25 of 1999, Government Notice 506, Republic of South Africa Government Gazette, Vol. 406, No 19974, Cape Town, 28 April 1999 * [[List of heritage sites in Northern Cape]]
==See also== * [[Provincial heritage resources authority]] * [[Provincial heritage site (South Africa)]] * [[Heritage objects (South Africa)]] * [[South African Heritage Resource Agency]] * [[Amafa aKwaZulu-Natali]] * [[Heritage Western Cape]] * [[National Monuments Council (South Africa and Namibia)]] * [[Historical Monuments Commission]] * [[List of heritage sites in Northern Cape]]

Provincial Heritage Resources Authorities: * [http://www.HWC.org.za Western Cape – Heritage Western Cape] * [http://www.heritagekzn.co.za/ KwaZulu Natal – Amafa aKwaZulu-Natali] * [http://www.heritagefreestate.co.za/ Free State – Heritage Free State] * [http://www.ecphra.org.za/ Eastern Cape – Eastern Cape Provincial Heritage Resources Authority] * [http://www.mpumalanga.gov.za/dept/scr.htm Mpumalanga – Mpumalanga Provincial Heritage Resources Authority] * [http://www.sac.limpopo.gov.za/ Limpopo – Limpopo Heritage Resources Authority] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20131115220723/http://www.nwpg.gov.za/dsac/ North West – North West Provincial Heritage Resources Authority] * [http://www.northern-cape.gov.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=321 Northern Cape – Ngwao-Boswa Jwa Kapa Bokone] * [http://www.sacr.gpg.gov.za/Pages/Heritage,Museums,GeographicalNamesandLanguage.aspx Gauteng – Provincial Heritage Resources Authority Gauteng]

revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox book | name = Pedagogy of the Oppressed | image = Pedagogy of the oppressed.jpg | caption = Cover | author = [[Paulo Freire]] | title_orig = Pedagogia do Oprimido | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = Portuguese | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = | pub_date = 1968 | english_pub_date = 1970 | media_type = | pages = | isbn = 9780826412768 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} {{Critical pedagogy}} '''''Pedagogy of the Oppressed''''' ({{lang-pt|Pedagogia do Oprimido}}), written by educator [[Paulo Freire]], proposes a [[pedagogy]] with a new relationship between teacher, student, and society. It was first published in Portuguese in 1968, and was translated by Myra Ramos into English and published in 1970.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pedagogyoftheoppressed.com/about/|title=About Pedagogy of the Oppressed|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111012165910/http://www.pedagogyoftheoppressed.com/about/|archivedate=2011-10-12|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2011-06-01}}</ref> The book is considered one of the foundational texts of [[critical pedagogy]].
Dedicated to the oppressed and based on his own experience helping Brazilian adults to read and write, Freire includes a detailed [[Marxist analysis|Marxist]] [[class analysis]] in his exploration of the relationship between the colonizer and the colonized.
In the book Freire calls traditional pedagogy the "[[banking model of education]]" because it treats the student as an empty vessel to be filled with knowledge, like a [[piggy bank]]. However, he argues for pedagogy to treat the learner as a co-creator of knowledge.
The book has sold over 750,000 copies worldwide.<ref>Publisher's Foreword in Freire, Paulo (2000). ''Pedagogy of the Oppressed''. New York: Continuum, p. 9.</ref>
==Summary== Translated into several languages, most editions of ''Pedagogy of the Oppressed'' contain at least one introduction/foreword, a preface, and four chapters.
The first chapter explores how [[oppression]] has been justified and how it is reproduced through a mutual process between the "oppressor" and the "oppressed" ([[oppressors–oppressed distinction]]). Examining how the balance of power between the colonizer and the colonized remains relatively stable, Freire admits that the powerless in society can be frightened of freedom. He writes, "Freedom is acquired by conquest, not by gift. It must be pursued constantly and responsibly. Freedom is not an ideal located outside of man; nor is it an idea which becomes myth. It is rather the indispensable condition for the quest for human completion".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/43929806|title=Pedagogy of the Oppressed|last=Freire|first=Paulo|publisher=Bloomsbury|isbn=9780826412768|edition=30th anniversary|location=New York|pages=47|oclc=43929806}}</ref> According to Freire, freedom will be the result of ''[[praxis (process)|praxis]]''—informed action—when a balance between theory and practice is achieved.
The second chapter examines the "banking" approach to education—a metaphor used by Freire that suggests students are considered empty bank accounts that should remain open to deposits made by the teacher. Freire rejects the "banking" approach, claiming it results in the [[dehumanization]] of both the students and the teachers. In addition, he argues the banking approach stimulates oppressive attitudes and practices in society. Instead, Freire advocates for a more world-mediated, mutual approach to education that encourages the co-creation of knowledge. According to Freire, this "authentic" approach to education must allow people to be aware of their incompleteness and strive to be more fully human. This attempt to use education as a means of consciously shaping the person and the society is called [[conscientization]], a term first coined by Freire in this book.
The third chapter discusses the idea that "to speak the true word is to transform the world".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/43929806|title=Pedagogy of the Oppressed|last=Freire|first=Paulo|publisher=Bloomsbury|isbn=9780826412768|edition=30th anniversary|location=New York|pages=87|oclc=43929806}}</ref> Freire developed the use of the term [[limit situation]] with regards to dimensions of human praxis. This is in line with [[:pt:Álvaro Vieira Pinto|Álvaro Vieira Pinto]]'s use of the word/idea in his "[[:pt:Consciência e Realidade Nacional |Consciência e Realidade Nacional]]", which Freire contends is "using the concept without the pessimistic character originally found in Jaspers" (Note 15, Chapter 3), in reference to [[Karl Jaspers]]'s notion of ''Grenzsituationen''.
The last chapter proposes [[dialogic]]s as an instrument to free the colonized, through the use of cooperation, unity, organization and cultural synthesis (overcoming problems in society to liberate human beings). This is in contrast to antidialogics, which use conquest, manipulation, cultural invasion, and the concept of divide and rule. Freire suggests that populist dialogue is a necessity to revolution; that impeding dialogue dehumanizes and supports the status quo. This is but one example of the [[dichotomies]] Freire identifies in the book; others include the student-teacher dichotomy and the colonizer-colonized dichotomy.
==Spread== Since the publication of the English edition in 1970, ''Pedagogy of the Oppressed'' has been widely adopted in America's teacher-training programs. A 2003 study by David Steiner and Susan Rozen determined that ''Pedagogy of the Oppressed'' was frequently assigned at top education schools.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://educationnext.org/skewedperspective/|title=Skewed Perspective - Education Next|date=2009-10-20|work=Education Next|access-date=2017-03-05|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Influences== The work was strongly influenced by [[Frantz Fanon]] and [[Karl Marx]]. One of Freire's dictums is that "there neither is, nor has ever been, an educational practice in zero space-time—neutral in the sense of being committed only to preponderantly abstract, intangible ideas."<ref>Freire, Paolo (2014) Pedagogy of Hope: Reliving Pedagogy of the Oppressed, New York: Bloomsbury, p.67.</ref>
[[Donaldo Macedo]], a former colleague of Freire and [[University of Massachusetts Boston]] professor, calls ''Pedagogy of the Oppressed'' a revolutionary text, and people in [[totalitarian]] states risk punishment reading it.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/43929806|title=Pedagogy of the Oppressed|last=Freire|first=Paulo|publisher=Bloomsbury|isbn=9780826412768|edition=30th anniversary|location=New York|pages=16|oclc=43929806}}</ref> During the [[Internal resistance to South African apartheid|South African anti-apartheid struggle]], ad-hoc copies of ''Pedagogy of the Oppressed'' were distributed underground as part of the "ideological weaponry" of various revolutionary groups like the [[Black Consciousness Movement]]. In the 1970s and 1980s the book was banned and kept clandestine.<ref>Archie Dick (2010) "Librarians and Readers in the South African Anti-Apartheid Struggle", public lecture given in Tampere Main Library, August 19, 2010.</ref>
==Critical reception==
In his article for the conservative ''[[City Journal (New York)|City Journal]]'', [[Sol Stern]] asserts that ''Pedagogy of the Oppressed'' ignores the traditional touchstones of Western education (''e.g.'', [[Jean-Jacques Rousseau|Rousseau]], [[John Dewey]], or [[Maria Montessori]]) and contains virtually none of the information typically found in traditional teacher education (''e.g.'', no discussion of [[curriculum]], [[Test (assessment)|testing]], or age-appropriate learning). To the contrary, Freire rejects traditional education as "official knowledge" that intends to oppress.<ref name="sol">Stern, Sol. [http://www.city-journal.org/2009/19_2_freirian-pedagogy.html "Pedagogy of the Oppressor"], ''City Journal'', Spring 2009, Vol. 19, no. 2</ref>
Stern also suggests that heirs to Freire's ideas have taken them to mean that since all education is political, "leftist math teachers who care about the oppressed have a right, indeed a duty, to use a pedagogy that, in Freire's words, 'does not conceal—in fact, which proclaims—its own political character.'"<ref>Stern, Sol. [http://www.city-journal.org/html/16_3_ed_school.html "'The Ed Schools' Latest—and Worst—Humbug"], ''City Journal'', Spring 2006, Vol. 16, No. 3.</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Brazil|Books}} * [[Adult education]] * [[Adult literacy]] * [[Information deficit model]] * ''[[Theatre of the Oppressed]]'' * [[Theatre pedagogy]]
==References== <references/>
==Bibliography== *Freire, Paulo. ''Pedagogy of the Oppressed.'' New York: Continuum, 2007. *Freire, Paulo. ''Pedagogy of the Oppressed, 30th Anniversary ed.'' New York: Continuum, 2006. *Rich Gibson, [http://www.pipeline.com/%7Erougeforum/freirecriticaledu.htm The Frozen Dialectics of Paulo Freire], in ''NeoLiberalism and Education Reform'', Hampton Press, 2006.
==External links== *{{wikiquote-inline}} *[http://marxists.anu.edu.au/subject/education/freire/pedagogy/index.htm ''Pedagogy of the Oppressed'' by Paulo Freire] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130307134728/http://www.comminit.com/en/node/27123 A detailed chapter by chapter summary] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-SOw55BU7yg Noam Chomsky, Howard Gardner, and Bruno della Chiesa discussion] about the book's impact and relevance to education today at the Askwith Forum commemorated the 45th anniversary of the publication of the book.
{{Freire}}
{{Youth empowerment}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox video game | title = Physicus | platforms = PC | released = 1999 | genre = Adventure, Educational }}
'''''Physicus: Save the World with Science!''''' is a 1999 educational adventure video game developed by HEUREKA-Klett Softwareverlag and published by Ruske & Puhretmaier Edutainment. It aims to teach players about physics concepts. It is part of a series that includes the chemistry-themed ''[[Chemicus]]'' (developed by Tivola Entertainment<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2003-02-02|title=Rescue of Chemist Rewards Patience|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-97186875.html}}</ref>) and biology-themed sequel<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2002-03-01|title=Bioscopia. (Software: focus on science).(and Answer This: Whales and Dolphins! from Tivola Publishing)(Product Announcement)|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-84969897.html|journal=T H E Journal (Technological Horizons In Education)}}</ref> ''[[Bioscopia]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mysterymanor.net/reviewphysicus.htm|title=Mystery Manor Physicus Review|date=2013-01-20|access-date=2017-12-23|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120050628/http://www.mysterymanor.net/reviewphysicus.htm|archivedate=2013-01-20|df=}}</ref> It was the second learning adventure game by Ruske & Pühretmaier Multimedia after the music-based ''[[Opera Fatal]]''. The game's website had a minigame called "PHYSICO DriveIn" that players could download and complete in to get the highscore, which would win them a free copy of a game by the studio.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.physikus.de/main.htm|title=Wayback Machine|date=2000-06-06|access-date=2017-12-23|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000606161136/http://www.physikus.de/main.htm|archivedate=2000-06-06|df=}}</ref> A sequel entitled '''''Physicus: The Return''''' was later released<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.klett-verlag.de/heureka/lernadventure/physicus2/set01.htm|title=Wayback Machine|date=2004-01-16|access-date=2017-12-23|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116171801/http://www.klett-verlag.de/heureka/lernadventure/physicus2/set01.htm|archivedate=2004-01-16|df=}}</ref>, and was remade for the iOS.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=EKMDBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA329&lpg=PA329&dq=%22Geograficus%22&source=bl&ots=kCEVWxYyTN&sig=yQ9rCIvveklcLdrwS9nRL_O_bHw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJosDB5KHYAhVIw7wKHVRtAKc4KBDoAQhbMAk#v=snippet&q=geograficus&f=false|title=ECGBL2011-Proceedings of the 5th European Conference on Games Based Learning: ECGBL2011|last=Gouscos|first=Dimitris|publisher=Academic Conferences and Publishing International|isbn=9781908272195|language=en}}</ref>
== Gameplay == Gameplay is similar to ''[[Myst]]'', in which players traverse through a series of computer generated static screens''.'' Players can investigate physical locations, manipulate items, and complete puzzles. to progress through the game.
The educational content covered four areas: Optics, Mechanics, Acoustics, and Electricity.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.physikus.de/main.htm|title=Wayback Machine|date=2000-06-06|access-date=2017-12-23|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000606161136/http://www.physikus.de/main.htm|archivedate=2000-06-06|df=}}</ref>
== Plot == When a meteorite collides with Earth, its planetary rotation ceases causing one hemisphere to be plunged into heat and the other into coldness. The player is tasked with using science to save the planet.
== Critical reception == ''Tap Repeatedly'' thought the game was made in the same vein as Myst, and complimented its "charming...lighthearted" design philosophy that effectively taught players in an engaging manner.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tap-repeatedly.com/Reviews/Physicus/Physicus.shtml|title=Four Fat Chicks -- Physicus Review|date=2015-11-20|access-date=2017-12-23|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151120134943/http://www.tap-repeatedly.com/Reviews/Physicus/Physicus.shtml|archivedate=2015-11-20|df=}}</ref> Allgame noted that the game's use of the metric system and British accent of the narrator could act as barriers to North American players.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=28772&tab=review|title=Physicus - Review - allgame|date=2014-11-16|access-date=2017-12-23|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141116222954/http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=28772&tab=review|archivedate=2014-11-16|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=28772|title=Physicus - Overview - allgame|date=2014-11-15|access-date=2017-12-23|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141115090041/http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=28772|archivedate=2014-11-15|df=}}</ref> Adventure Spiele wrote that the game would be able to teach some physics concepts to even the uninitiated.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.adventurespiele.net/reviews-req-showcontent-id-151.htm|title=avsn.de Heureka - Physikus 1 - Und Physik wird zum Abenteuer Review|date=2016-03-09|access-date=2017-12-23|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309081954/http://www.adventurespiele.net/reviews-req-showcontent-id-151.htm|archivedate=2016-03-09|df=}}</ref> Quandaryland thought it would be a shame if the game's educational nature turned people off an experience as enjoyable as many non-educational titles.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.quandaryland.com/jsp/dispArticle.jsp?index=483|title=Physicus Review by Quandary|date=2006-01-09|access-date=2017-12-23|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060109081618/http://www.quandaryland.com/jsp/dispArticle.jsp?index=483|archivedate=2006-01-09|df=}}</ref> Adventure Gamers noted the game's potential application within schools.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.adventuregamers.com/display.php?id=250|title=Adventure Gamers : Physicus|date=2006-01-03|access-date=2017-12-23|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060103201654/http://www.adventuregamers.com/display.php?id=250|archivedate=2006-01-03|df=}}</ref>
=== Awards and nominations === * 1999 Padi seal of approval (6 mice rating)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mediengewalt.de/spiele/beste-lernspiele-kinder-12-jahre.shtml|title=Beste Lernspiele für Kinder ab 12 Jahre (und andere Altersgruppen)|website=www.mediengewalt.de|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> * 2000 Comenius seal<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mediengewalt.de/spiele/beste-lernspiele-kinder-12-jahre.shtml|title=Beste Lernspiele für Kinder ab 12 Jahre (und andere Altersgruppen)|website=www.mediengewalt.de|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20000606161136/http://www.physikus.de/main.htm Main page] * ''[https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-71681614.html Multimedia Schools review]'' [[Category:1999 video games]] [[Category:Adventure games]] [[Category:Educational video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Germany]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Windows-only games]]

page.title: RMIT School of Media and Communication

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox university school | name = School of Media and Communication | parent = College of Design and Social Context,
[[RMIT University|Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology]] | image = | head_label = Head | head = Professor Martyn Hook[http://mams.rmit.edu.au/xgwtiyphndw5.pdf Annual Report 2011], RMIT University, p.36, retrieved 12 October 2012 | campus = [[RMIT City|City]] | affiliations = | website = [http://www.rmit.edu.au/MEDIACOMMUNICATION School of Media and Communication] }} RMIT's '''School of Media and Communication''' is an [[Australia]]n [[tertiary education]] school within the College of Design and Social Context at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology ([[RMIT University]]), located in [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]. The school hosts the university's [[Advertising]], [[Animation]], [[audio visual|Audio/Visual]], [[Communication Design]], [[Creative Writing]], [[Publishing|Editing and Publishing]], [[filmmaking|Film and Television]], [[Journalism]], [[Mass Media|Media]], [[Music|Music Industry]], [[Multimedia]], [[Photography]], Professional Communication (a hybrid-degree which crosses Journalism, Media and Public Relations), [[Public Relations]] and [[Video Games]] programs. The school was formed by the merger of the [[RMIT School of Creative Media]] and [[RMIT School of Applied Communication]] on 6 July 2009.[http://www.rmit.edu.au/browse;ID=ka7itw3r2utb1 RMIT officially announces School of Media and Communication] - Openline (RMIT News) - 6 July 2009 ==Location== The school is headquartered in Building 9 (RMIT's historical radio communications building) on Bowen Street at the [[RMIT City]] campus, located in the "RMIT Quarter" at the northern end of the [[Melbourne CBD]]. It moved in 2010 from Building 6, but because of its size still has staff in other buildings in the city campus. The school is also located in Building 94 on Cardigan Street in the "Carlton Precinct" of the [[RMIT City]] campus. ==Programs== The School of Media and Communication provides programs that supports students to launch or advance their career in communication, design games and media. ==AFI Research Collection== The [[Australian Film Institute]] (AFI) Research Collection is a non-lending, specialist film and television industry resource. It opened in the mid-1970s as the George Lugg Library, and was a joint venture between the AFI and the Victorian Federation of Film Societies. In 2002 it became an auspice of the RMIT School of Media and Communication, in conjunction with the AFI.[http://www.afiresearch.rmit.edu.au/] ==Journals and publications== The school publishes Journals and publications, the most notable is ''Communication, Politics & Culture''(formerly known as Southern Review: Communication, Politics & Culture) is an interdisciplinary journal focusing on the connections between communication and politics, published twice a year. It was first published in 1963 (as the ''Australian Journal of Literary Studies'') by the English Department of the [[University of Adelaide]]. It gained a reputation in the 1980s through the publication of analyses in literary and cultural theory. It relocated from the University of Adelaide to the Communication Department of [[Monash University]] in 1995, before it permanently became part of the RMIT School of Media and Communication in 2000. ==Notable alumni== {{Main|List of Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology people}} *[[Allan Briggs (Founder of Briggs Communications)|Allan Briggs]] - [[crisis communication]] expert and Managing Director of Briggs Communications *[[Julian de Stoop]] - journalist and head of [[Fox Sports News]] (Melbourne Bureau) *[[Bob Isherwood]] - Worldwide creative director of [[Saatchi & Saatchi]] *[[Nick Johnston (journalist)|Nick Johnston]] - [[Victoria (Australia)|Victorian]] state political reporter with the [[Nine Network]] *[[Rebecca Maddern]] - national news presenter with the [[Seven Network]] *[[Chris Masters (writer)|Chris Masters]], [[Public Service Medal (Australia)|PSM]] - [[Walkley Awards|Walkley]] and [[Logie Award]] winning journalist *[[Mariko Oi]] - BBC journalist and presenter *[[Megan Spencer]] - journalist and documentary film maker *[[James Talia]] - award-winning journalist and [[Europe]]an correspondent with the [[Nine Network]] *[[Robert James Thomson|Robert Thomson]] - CEO of [[News Corp Australia]], former editor of the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' and ''[[The Times]]'' *[[James Wan]] - co-creator of the [[Saw (franchise)|Saw]] film franchise *[[Leigh Whannell]] - co-creator of the [[Saw (franchise)|Saw]] film franchise ==See also== *[[RMIT University]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120306001651/http://www.rmit.edu.au/mediacommunication Website of the School of Media and Communication] {{Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology}} {{Coord|37|48|28|S|144|57|48|E|type:edu_region:AU-VIC|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:RMIT School of Media and Communication}} [[Category:RMIT University schools|Media and Communication]] [[Category:Film schools in Australia]] [[Category:Animation schools]] [[Category:Audio engineering schools]] [[Category:Broadcasting schools]] [[Category:Design schools]] [[Category:Digital media schools]] [[Category:Journalism schools in Oceania]] [[Category:Australian journalism organisations]]
